tossups.question: Knives are placed in the mouths of this figure and a noble warrior princess to get a ruler to release the latter’s father in the subplot of a “Romance.” The thought of a potion that reforms “golden lotuses” comforts this figure, who later captures the bandit “Leopard Skin.” This figure comments on how the genders of two rabbits running side-by-side are indistinguishable after revealing (*) her combed hair adorned with golden flowers. The Khan gifts a camel to this figure during an eponymous ballad set during the Rouran invasion of the Northern Wèi. Because this figure lacks an elder brother, she replaces her father when answering a conscription notice. For 10 points, name this cross-dressing Chinese heroine.
tossups.answer: Mùlán [or Huā Mùlán] (The works mentioned are the Romance of Sui and Tang, the Female Mulan, and the Ballad of Mulan.)
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, RMP - World Mythology> ~27606~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: A poem titled for these things compares “life” to a “broken-winged bird / that cannot fly” and a “barren field” without these things. The lines “Good morning, daddy! Ain’t you heard?” open and close a long poem titled for a “Montage” of one of these things. A collection titled for a “Keeper” of these things included the poems “I, Too” and (*) “Mother to Son.” It is hypothesized that one of these things “crust[s] and sugar[s] over” “like a syrupy sweet” in a 1951 poem in which it also “fester[s] like a sore.” Potential answers to a question about one of these things include “Does it stink like rotten meat?” and “does it explode?” For 10 points, Langston Hughes’s poem “Harlem” asks what happens to one of what things “deferred?”
tossups.answer: dreams [accept a dream deferred; accept Montage of a Dream Deferred; accept The Dream Keeper]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Poetry> ~28692~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: A black string belt worn by members of this faith symbolically separates the heart from the genitals during prayer. Robes worn by dancing maidens may have inspired this faith’s men to wear pocketless white robes that double as burial shrouds. White garments with black or dark blue stripes worn by members of this faith have knotted fringes on their four corners and are prohibited from being a blend of (*) wool and linen. Sable, marten, and fox tails can be used to create the cylindrical fur hats worn by a sect of this faith, whose men often wear black suits and have sidelocks. Adherents of this faith may obey head-covering mandates by wearing sheitel (“shy-tell”) wigs or brimless caps. For 10 points, name this faith whose men wear kippot, or yarmulkes (“YAH-mah-kahs”).
tossups.answer: Judaism [accept Jews or Jewish people; accept the Jewish faith; accept Orthodox Judaism or Conservative Judaism or Reform Judaism; accept Hasidism or Chassidism (“HAH-sid-ism”) or Hasidic Judaism or Chassidic Judaism; accept Ashkenazi Jews; prompt on Orthodox or Conservative or Reform] (The unnamed clues are, in order, the gartel, the kittel, the tallit, and the shtreimel.)
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - Jewish Practice> ~28222~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: This process necessitated the creation of highly-bureaucratized states according to Karl Wittfogel’s controversial book Oriental Despotism. The Shaluf Stele contains evidence of a structure used for this process sometimes named after Necho II. Rats legendarily caused the destruction of a structure used for this process in Ma’rib in 570 CE. This process was accomplished by ancient Iranian (*) qanats and lever-like shadufs. Precursors to Archimedes’s Screw have been suggested to aid in this process at the Hanging Gardens of Babylon. Overdoing this process can lead to overdrafting and salination. For 10 points, name this task accomplished by ditches that filled up during the flooding of the Nile.
tossups.answer: irrigation [accept word forms like irrigating or irrigate; accept moving water or water management; accept damming; accept flood control or flood management or flood prevention before “floods” are mentioned; prompt on farming or agriculture]
tossups.metadata: Joseph Krol, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~28428~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: A form of this quantity for a galaxy equals an observed form of this quantity over the sine of inclination. This quantity is measured via the tangent-point method at distances less than the galactocentric radius. Inferring this quantity from spectral line width enables estimation of a galaxy’s luminosity with the (*) Tully–Fisher relation. This quantity’s deviation from a Keplerian profile is evidence for dark matter, as shown on the vertical axis of galaxy rotation curves. Hubble’s law equates a form of this quantity with Hubble’s constant times proper distance. Changes in frequency depend on relative values of this quantity in the Doppler effect. For 10 points, name this quantity measured in kilometers per second.
tossups.answer: velocity [accept rotational velocity or recession velocity or recessional velocity or radial velocity; prompt on v; prompt on speed or rotational orbital speed; reject “angular velocity”] (The lead-in describes rotational velocity as observed radial velocity over the sine of inclination.)
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Science - Astronomy> ~27413~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: One of these events prompted Brazil to establish the Proálcool (“pro-AHL-cool”) program. The so-called “MEOW Speech” responding to one of these events was delivered by a president whose namesake doctrine, crafted by Zbigniew Brzezinski (“ZBIG-nee-ev brr-zheh-ZIN-ski”), called for using military force to prevent future events of this type. One of these events gave way to a “glut” in the following decade thanks to the (*) Prudhoe Bay complex coming fully online. In response to one of these events, Richard Nixon signed the National Maximum Speed Limit law. One of these events was launched by King Faisal during the Yom Kippur War and led to a turn away from the Big Three of Detroit. For 10 points, name these events, two of which in the 1970s were caused by a decision to block exports by OPEC.
tossups.answer: oil crisis [or energy crisis; accept oil embargo or oil shock or oil shortage or energy shortage or energy shock or fuel crisis or gas crisis; prompt on recession or embargo]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~27728~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: An early chain selling a “spud” variant of this food built upon Pennsylvania Dutch recipes for fasnachts. Prior to Stonewall, the first modern LGBT uprising occurred at Cooper’s, a business named for this food. The so-called “king” of this food, Ted Ngoy (“noy”), helped Cambodian refugees open stores selling this food in California. In 2003, the FDA ordered a Portland, Oregon store called (*) Voodoo to stop adding NyQuil to this food. In 1997, the city of Boston gave a parade for the retirement of Fred the Baker, who advertised for a fast food chain named for this food. Bite-sized versions of this food called Timbits are offered by Canada’s Tim Hortons. For 10 points, name this signature food of Krispy Kreme.
tossups.answer: donuts [or doughnuts; accept jelly donuts; accept donut holes; accept spudnuts or potato doughnuts; prompt on breakfast pastry]
tossups.metadata: Jeffrey Liu, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~27956~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: Queen Victoria’s preference for the No. 7 size of these tools led to Winsor & Newton’s Series 7 line of them. The monk Philibert names a flat type of these tools with a round tip. The principle of gúfǎ, or “bone method,” is central to using Chinese ones of these tools, which are held upright. Prized examples of these tools are made from kolinsky sable. These tools may be used in conjunction with an offset, diamond-shaped (*) knife to employ the contrasting techniques of impasto and sfumato. This tool is used to apply gold leaf in gilding by harnessing static electricity. A ferrule secures the handle of this tool to a tuft of fur. For 10 points, pens and what tools are used in Chinese calligraphy because their bristles hold ink?
tossups.answer: paintbrushes [or brushes; accept máobǐ or ink brush; prompt on bǐ; reject “gāngbĭ” or “pen”]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~28154~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: Henrietta Lacks’s doctor George Gey popularized the in vitro use of this protein harvested from rat tails. The letter “O” is unusually common in this protein’s one-letter amino acid sequence. This protein’s type I (“one”) isoform is used to coat cell culture plates. Matrigel is a mixture of this protein with laminin that mimics a basement membrane by adhering to (*) integrins. G. N. Ramachandran proved this protein is a right-handed helix of three left-handed glycine-rich helices. Cells need vitamin C to make this protein’s numerous hydroxy·proline residues. Fibers of this protein guarantee the stiffness of the extracellular matrix. For 10 points, name this component of connective tissue, the most common protein in humans.
tossups.answer: collagen [or collagen IV or collagen I] (O is the one-letter symbol for hydroxyproline.)
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~27659~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: A reveille (“REV-uh-lee”) in this collection concludes by stating how “there’ll be time enough for sleep” when the journey’s over. This collection opens by describing a beacon on Clee Hill and people singing “God Save the Queen.” “The wood’s in trouble” from a gale approaching the title location in one poem in this collection. A poem in this collection notes (*) “Mithridates, he died old” and “malt does more than Milton can / To justify God’s ways to man.” This collection includes a poem in which the laurel “withers quicker than the rose” for a title character who won his town a race. For 10 points, name this collection that contains “Terence, this is stupid stuff” and “To An Athlete Dying Young” by A. E. Housman.
tossups.answer: A Shropshire Lad
tossups.metadata: Anuttam Ramji, Literature - British - Poetry> ~25968~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: The study of this class of particles motivates C·A·R algebras, which complement CCR algebras. The Hubbard model features a lattice of this class of particles. The antisymmetric wave functions of these particles cause them to be described by anti-commuting fields in the spin–statistics theorem. Examples of these particles that behave as their own antiparticles were hypothesized by Ettore Majorana. Baryons (*) exemplify the “composite” type of these particles whose “elementary” type is exemplified by quarks and leptons. The Pauli exclusion principle applies to these particles, which have half-integer spin. For 10 points, name these particles that are contrasted with bosons and named for an Italian physicist.
tossups.answer: fermions [accept Majorana fermions; prompt on neutrinos or electrons or quarks or leptons by asking “what broader class of particles does that belong to?”; allow players to receive this prompt multiple times]
tossups.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Science - Physics> ~14878~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: During one of these events, William Boghurst wrote his Loimographia. John Graunt gained entrance to the Royal Society through several “bills” he compiled during these events. Queen Elizabeth I threatened to hang anyone who followed her to Windsor Castle during one of these events in 1563. Edward III issued the Ordinance of Laborers to fix (*) wages during one of these events. Daniel Defoe kept a journal of a “year” during one of these events which may have been ended by the Great Fire of London. An urban legend claims that the nursery rhyme “Ring Around the Rosie” originated during one of these events. For 10 points, Europe’s population was nearly halved during what type of event in the mid-1300s?
tossups.answer: plagues [accept Black Death or Black Plague or bubonic plague; accept bubonic plague outbreaks; prompt on generic answers like disease outbreaks or pandemics or epidemics or pestilences, by asking “of what disease?”]
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, History - European - Misc> ~28121~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: A 2010 album by Elīna Garanča (“ga-RAHN-cha”) is named for this piece, which was based on a piece by Sebastián Iradier (“ee-rahd-YAIR”) that the composer mistook for a folk song. Dorothy Dandridge’s character sings an adaptation of this piece called “Dat’s Love” in a movie musical titled for that character with the surname “Jones.”In this piece, the cellos play an ostinato on the rhythm [read slowly] “dotted eighth, sixteenth, eighth, eighth” before the singer enters on a (*) chromatically descending melody. The singer repeats the warning, “If I love you, beware!” in this aria while outside of a cigarette factory, during which she tosses a flower to Don José (“joh-ZAY”). This aria compares love to a rebellious bird. For 10 points, give this aria named for a Cuban dance, sung by Carmen.
tossups.answer: Habanera from Carmen [or “L’amour est un oiseau rebelle”; accept “Love is a rebellious bird” before “rebellious” is read; prompt on Carmen or Carmen Jones before read] (The movie musical is Carmen Jones.)
tossups.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Opera> ~27519~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: A 2024 omnibus reform bill sponsored by this politician that stripped I·N·C·A·A film funding failed to pass while he was in Israel. A month earlier at Davos, this politician declared, “I am here today to tell you that the West is in danger.” In his campaign memoir, this politician described being beaten by his bus driver father and how his only close friend was his sister and campaign manager, Karina. This one-time executive at (*) Corporación (“core-pore-ah-see-OHN”) América often cosplays as General AnCap and accented his campaign speeches by using a chainsaw to symbolize the state agencies he’d cut. In November 2023, this man defeated the Peronist-backed Sergio Massa. For 10 points, name this Libertarian President of Argentina.
tossups.answer: Javier Milei [or Javier Gerardo Milei]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~28051~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: In an Alejandra Pizarnik poem titled for removing one of these objects, the speaker laments “The bad light is near and nothing is real.” This is the last title object of a poem that states “Each is another and no other: / Crossing and vanishing.” A poem titled for one of these objects describes trees as “pillars of magic” that create “corridors of a dissolving autumn.” The speaker claims “I go among your body as among the world” in a poem titled for one of these objects that depicts a (*) “river that goes curving, / advances and retreats.” That 584-line poem titled for one of these objects begins “willow of crystal, a poplar of water.” The sun names an Aztec example of, for 10 points, what object that titles an Octavio Paz poem?
tossups.answer: stone [accept piedra; accept “Sun Stone” or “Piedra del sol”; accept “Wind, Water, Stone” or “Viento, Agua, Piedra”; accept “Extracting the Stone of Madness” or “Extracción de la piedra de locura”; reject synonyms like “rocks”]
tossups.metadata: Sinecio Morales, Literature - World and Miscellaneous

tossups.question: Despite not having this affiliation, Grace Growdon Galloway had her property seized by coverture laws. Charles Inglis founded a university as part of a group of these people who left a city on Evacuation Day. Boston King received a certificate of freedom as one of the many examples of these people with African heritage who settled in Nova Scotia. Colonel Tye and other members of this affiliation formed the (*) Ethiopian Regiment after Lord Dunmore’s Proclamation. A militia of this affiliation was defeated at the Battle of Kings Mountain. People with this affiliation were punished with tarring and feathering. For 10 points, name these people who sided with the British and fought the Patriots during the American Revolution.
tossups.answer: Loyalists [or Tories; or Royalists; or King’s Men; accept Black Loyalists; accept answers such as supporters of the king; accept supporters of the British before “British” is read; prompt on enslaved people or people with African heritage by asking “what political affiliation did they have?”]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - Pre-1865> ~28773~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

tossups.question: In one essay, this author claims the “audio-animatronics” of Disneyland’s Pirates of the Caribbean create “a fantasy world more real than reality.” This author relates how a “family size” hotel minibar averted a disaster with a computer system in the essay “How to Travel with a Salmon.” In a novel by this author, the password “no” is used to log in a computer which generates text about “telluric currents” and is called (*) Abulafia. Belbo, Diotallevi, and Casaubon use that computer to create “The Plan,” a Knights Templar conspiracy theory, in a novel by this author. William of Baskerville investigates monastery murders in a novel by this author. For 10 points, name this Italian author of Foucault’s Pendulum and The Name of the Rose.
tossups.answer: Umberto Eco (The first work is Travels in Hyperreality.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~28502~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: The soloist in this composer’s first cello concerto enters with the melody [read slowly] “G, F-flat, up to C-flat, long B-flat,” which he transposed and quoted in a later string quartet. This composer’s first violin concerto consists of a nocturne, scherzo (“SCAIR-tzo”), passacaglia (“pahss-uh-CALL-ya”), and burlesque. This composer wrote his second piano concerto in F major for his son Maxim. While staying in Dresden to write the score to the film Five Days, Five Nights, this composer wrote a C minor (*) string quartet, his eighth, which he dedicated “to the victims of fascism and the war.” This composer wrote an “invasion theme” for his seventh symphony. For 10 points, the cryptogram D-S-C-H represents what composer of the Leningrad Symphony?
tossups.answer: Dmitri Shostakovich [or Dmitri Dmitriyevich Shostakovich; prompt on Shosty]
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~27774~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: This philosopher addressed the anti-slavery pamphlet “Emancipate Your Colonies!” to the French legislature. This philosopher argued that homosexuality does not “rob women” and should therefore be decriminalized in the essay “Offences Against One’s Self.” A controversial principle developed by this philosopher follows the dictates of mankind’s “two sovereign masters.” This philosopher developed the (*) “act” form of a philosophy that considers the intensity and duration of experiences as part of a felicific (“fel-ih-SIF-ik”) calculus. This philosopher formulated a moral theory that uses net pleasure and pain to calculate the greatest happiness for the greatest number. For 10 points, name this founder of utilitarianism.
tossups.answer: Jeremy Bentham
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~27800~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: These compounds migrate and insert into a carbon-zirconium bond in the propagation step of a Kaminsky catalyst. These compounds are the oxidation products when a free radical polymer disproportionates. Catalytic cracking is used to produce these short-chain molecules at an oil refinery. These compounds coordinate aluminum to form vinyl cations that eliminate a beta-hydride in the mechanism of a (*) Ziegler–Natta catalyst. The kinked chain of an unsaturated fatty acid is one of these compounds. Industrial plastics like PVC or PE are polymers of these compounds, which have formulas of the form “C n H two n.” For 10 points, name these compounds that react together to form poly·olefins and have a carbon-carbon double bond.
tossups.answer: alkenes (“al-KEENS”) [or polyalkenes; acceptolefins or polyolefins until it is read; prompt on hydrocarbons; prompt on monomers until it is read; prompt on unsaturated fatty acid or fatty acid until it is read; listen carefully and reject “alkanes” (“al-KANES”) or “alkynes” (“al-KINES”); reject “plastics”]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~27451~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: In 1903, a Swedish feminist named Lizzy Lind af Hageby snuck into a university in this city and exposed a vivisection scandal in the Brown Dog Affair. Common Cause promoted a 1913 Great Pilgrimage that ended in this city and attracted 50,000 supporters of the NUWSS. Prisoners at this city’s Holloway Prison were temporarily released via the (*) Cat and Mouse Act to counter hunger strikes. Women in this city were targeted by a man who wrote the “Dear Boss” and “From Hell” letters. The WSPU was founded in this capital city by Emmeline Pankhurst to advocate for the right of women to vote. For 10 points, name this capital city where the Whitechapel Murders were committed by Jack the Ripper.
tossups.answer: London

bonuses.leadin: The ratio of debt to this quantity is a measure of a company’s financial leverage. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity. Broadly, companies can be financed either by taking on debt or by increasing this quantity by selling shares.
Debt is often said to be cheaper than equity because interest payments on debt can be deducted from one’s income, lowering the amount of these fees paid to the IRS.

In a taxless world, debt and equity financing are equivalent by a theorem named for Merton Miller and an economist from this country. Competitive markets achieve a condition named for an economist from this country by the first welfare theorem.
answers: Italy [or Italia; accept the Italian Republic or Kingdom of Italy] (The economists are Franco Modigliani and Vilfredo Pareto; the first welfare theorem states that competitive markets are Pareto efficient.)
bonuses.metadata: Vincent Du, Social Science - Economics> ~23227~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: The film The Lives of Others mentions a government attempt to conceal high suicide rates in this country. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, whose high suicide rates were linked to repression by a secret police led by Erich Mielke.
This publication attributed East Germany’s suicide rate to its prevalence among the elderly. In 1962, this German newspaper’s offices were raided after criticizing Konrad Adenauer’s defense policy.

Georg Dreyman wrote the Der Spiegel article on a smuggled one of these devices, since all others were registered with the East German government. The QWERTY keyboard was developed for these devices whose keys punch an inked ribbon.
answers: East Germany [accept Ostdeutschland accept DDR or GDR; accept German Democratic Republic or Deutsche Demokratische Republik; prompt on Germany or Deutschland] (The secret police is the Stasi.)

bonuses.leadin: A campaign button declared, “Vote for [this man] this time. You can vote for Bryan anytime!” as a reference to how many times his opponent William Jennings Bryan had already run for office. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this president and future Chief Justice who succeeded Theodore Roosevelt.
In 1908, Bryan’s running mate was John W. Kern, who was twice-defeated running for governor of this state. Another candidate in 1908, Eugene Debs, was born in this state.
Though he failed to gain the Independence Party nomination in 1908, this tycoon used that party to hurt the chances of Bryan. This isolationist owned the New York Journal newspaper.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~22106~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

bonuses.leadin: This species has 110 genes named for its phenotype unc (“UNK”) for “uncoordinated.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this model organism that swims around either by “thrashing” or “crawling.” Phenotypes of this translucent nematode are often named for how they move.
C. elegans alternates between weathervaning—a form of chemotaxis—and pirouetting, which is this type of undirected random tumbling motion that’s not in the direction of a stimulus.
The allele that causes C. elegans to roll is a useful selection marker for gene uptake since it has this property. Alleles with this property are symbolized by capital letters.
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Biology> ~22550~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: In its original usage, this phrase is followed by a sentence that includes the parenthetical “for it is in London that our scene lies.” For 10 points each:
parts: Give this seven-word phrase that opens the novel Paul Clifford. This phrase inspired a bad fictional opening line–contest named for its writer.
Edward Bulwer-Lytton’s other quotes include one from his play Richelieu that states that this object “is mightier than the sword.”

Bulwer-Lytton helped popularize the phrase “no stone left unturned,” which appeared in this author’s play Heraclidae (“hair-uh-KLL-die”). The title character of a play by this author rides away in a chariot with the bodies of her victims.
answers: “It was a dark and stormy night” (The contest is the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest.)
the pen [accept “the pen is mightier than the sword”]
bonuses.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~23223~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the influence of fashion designer Thierry Mugler (“tee-AIR-ee moog-LAIR”). For 10 points each:
parts: For Mugler’s 1993 show, pioneering trans model Connie Girl wore a bejeweled pair of boots that doubled as these fashion accessories which typically attach to a belt and go over the shoulder to hold up pants or skirts.
Mugler designed some of the outfits for a 2009 music video by this artist that opens in a prison. Franc Fernandez designed a dress for this artist made entirely of raw beef.

The Sailor Moon character Saturn often appears in black dresses inspired by Mugler’s collection of these meticulously decorated fashion items. They’re known by a two-word French term for “high dressmaking” and contrasted with ready-to-wear.
answers: Lady Gaga [or Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta; prompt on Gaga alone]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~23783~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: The book “Liberalism and the Limits of [this concept]” popularized communitarianism in American philosophy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ethical concept that John Rawls defines as fairness. This concept’s “procedural” form is related to due process.
To ensure fairness, Rawls’s “original position” argument proposes that parties deciding societal principles have their own identity and position in society hidden by this metaphorical object.

This philosopher critiqued the original position’s “possessive individualism” in Liberalism and the Limits of Justice. The popular online lecture series Justice: What’s the Right Thing to Do? was taught by this thinker at Harvard.
answers: justice [accept Justice as Fairness; accept Liberalism and the Limits of Justice; accept procedural justice]
bonuses.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~23251~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: This quantity increases with each summed Hilbert space in the standard construction of Fock space. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity that, by definition, is well-defined in a Fock state. In their original usage, creation and annihilation operators alter this quantity.
Applying the annihilation operator N times yields this Fock state, in which there are zero particles. This state is named for space that contains no matter.

This Englishman-turned-Floridian introduced creation and annihilation operators. This physicist predicted the existence of the positron via his relativistic generalization of the Schrödinger equation.
answers: Paul Dirac [or Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac; accept the Dirac equation]
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Physics> ~23706~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: According to Gerald of Wales, an elderly descendant of Ossory’s pagans removed the skin of one of these animals after she received her last rites. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these animals whose skins granted Sigmund and Sinfjötli (“sin-FEEYOT-lee”) the power to take on seven men. The Aesir transfigured Váli into one of these animals just before he dismembered his brother Narfi.
After blaspheming God, Ossory’s howling pagans were cursed with lycanthropy following this saint’s prayers. This saint drove out Ireland’s snakes.
In Norse myth, wolf and bear skins could transform a man into one of these frenzied warriors who may have fought while high on mushrooms.
answers: Saint Patrick [accept Saint Padraig or Saint Patricius or Saint Padrig]
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~22585~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: A Talkative Man created by this author foolishly purchases a giant tractor, but is relieved of its costs when an earthquake sends it down a well. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Tamil author who set a series of stories around the town of Malgudi, which he created in his novel Swami and Friends.

In another story, the Talkative Man claims he cut off the toes of one of these animals, but likely poached the animal instead. Balram writes letters to Wēn Jiābǎo in an Aravind Adiga novel titled for one of these animals.
Narayan was championed in the West by this Catholic author of novels like The Power and the Glory and Our Man in Havana.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23187~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: Three actors portray this composer’s “Eye,” “Hand,” and “Mouth” in Grace McLean’s musical In the Green. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this medieval composer of “O viridissima virga” who translated visions into the first known morality play Ordo Virtutum.

Hildegard’s music is written in this manner because she never learned to play an instrument. This Italian term refers to music without instrumental accompaniment and names a kind of vocal group exemplified by Pentatonix.
McLean used this technique to repeat vocal parts for In the Green. Minimalist composers may use this technique to “phase” recordings by connecting two ends of a magnetic tape.
answers: Hildegard von Bingen [or St. Hildegard; or Hildegardis Bingensis; reject “Bingen”]
looping [prompt on descriptions like recording and replaying parts or repeating parts]
bonuses.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Miscellaneous> ~22721~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: Apocryphally, the blood of followers of this religion was used to power mills and create bread during the conquest of Gorgan. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this religion whose followers began converting to Islam after the fall of the Sassanids and Arab conquest of Persia.
al-Mutawakkil cut down a cypress planted by Zoroaster and used it to build part of a spiral minaret in this city, whose “anarchy” resulted in Abbasid leadership moving to Baghdad.
Parsis fled to India after the takeover of Persia by this first caliphate ruled by Umar and Uthman. The Umayyads supplanted this caliphate after the death of Ali.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - World - Middle Eastern> ~22646~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: The epigraph to Mario Puzo’s The Godfather, “Behind every great fortune there is a crime,” is attributed to this author. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French author, who included La Cousine Bette (“la kuzin bet”) and Eugenie Grandet (“oo-zhay-NEE gron-DAY”) in his work The Human Comedy.

That quote is said by this thief, who is based on real-life criminal turned police chief Eugène Vidocq (“vee-DOCK”). This character tries to convince Eugène de Rastignac (“RAS-tin-YAK”) to pursue Victorine, before his identity “Cheat-Death” is found out.
Puzo’s line “I’m gonna make him an offer he can’t refuse” is often said to be a paraphrase from this Balzac novel, whose title “father” is abandoned by his daughters.
answers: Vautrin (“vo-TRAN”) [or Jacques Collin or Abbé Carlos Herrera; prompt on Dodgedeath or Trompe-la-Mort]
Le Père Goriot (“le pair GOH-ree-oh”) [or Old Goriot or Father Goriot]
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~22674~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: Isabella Karle pioneered an experimental approach to solve molecular structures using this technique, but she was snubbed for the 1985 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, which was awarded to her husband instead. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this analytical technique that was mainly pioneered in the 20th century by female chemists like Kathleen Lonsdale and Rosalind Franklin.
This crystallographer was awarded a Nobel for her determination of the structures of penicillin and insulin.
No women were awarded Nobel Prizes in Chemistry between Hodgkin’s win in 1964 and 2009, when Ada Yonath won for crystallizing this cellular structure that synthesizes proteins.
answers: X-ray crystallography [or X-ray diffraction; or XRD; prompt on X-rays; prompt on crystallization or crystal growth or crystal formation]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22148~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: A vehicle developed for this sport appears on the official logo of Peachtree City, Georgia, where there’s almost one such vehicle per person. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this water-hungry sport whose courses include Augusta National, which hosts the Masters.

Golf carts are widely used in The Villages, a retirement community about 45 miles northwest of this city. Reedy Creek Energy Solutions services the residents of the planned community of Celebration in this city’s suburbs.

The golf cart was first used at Thunderbird Country Club in this region, home to the resort of Cathedral City. An annual event named for this region is held at the Empire Polo Club in the city of Indio.
answers: golf [accept answers such as professional golf or PGA golf; accept golf carts]
Coachella Valley [accept Coachella Music Festival; prompt on Greater Palm Springs or Southern California]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - United States> ~22851~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: In a painting, a man performing this action next to the Eiffel Tower appears above a man with two faces. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this action that is also performed by a couple kissing in the painting The Birthday as well as in a painting that depicts its artist cradling his wife in Vitebsk.
This artist and his wife Bela Rosenfeld appear in his paintings The Birthday and Over the Town. This Belarusian artist created I and the Village.
The Eiffel Tower also appears in a Chagall self-portrait that is partially titled for him having this specific condition as he works on a painting of a cow.
answers: flying [accept synonyms such as floating or soaring or levitating or hovering; accept rising or falling]

extra fingers [accept descriptions and equivalents such as having more than five fingers on one hand or an unusual number of fingers; accept Self-Portrait with Seven Fingers; accept polydactyly; reject “having six fingers” or answers indicating a specific number of fingers that is not seven]
bonuses.metadata: Anthony Troullier, Fine Arts - Painting - European 1600-1945> ~22710~ <Editor: Ganon Evans

bonuses.leadin: Students in this author’s two-semester survey class at Wellesley College were required to memorize the letter grades he gave to Russian writers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author who gave Tolstoy an A+ and Dostoevsky a C-. His own novels include Lolita.

Since Nabokov didn’t assign grades to his own novels, we’ll have to go to Goodreads to see that Jim gave this “heartfelt story of a hapless antihero” four stars. This Nabokov novel centers on a professor at Waindell College.

“Dan” on Goodreads only gave 3.5 stars to The Stories of Vladimir Nabokov but did enjoy this one about “an aging couple… at a loss about what to do about their institutionalized son.” This story opens with the couple choosing a birthday gift of “a basket with ten different fruit jellies in ten little jars.”
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - American - Misc> ~22876~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: Proving Kleene’s (“KLAY-nee’s”) theorem involves developing an algorithm to convert these strings into DFAs. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these strings used for pattern matching in text with tools like Python’s “re” module. A textbook application of these strings is to check whether an email address is valid.

This Ken Thompson–developed command line tool, which is commonly used alongside sed and awk, prints lines that match a given regular expression. This tool’s “c” flag makes it return only the number of matches in each queried file.
A regular expression can define a “regular” one of these sets. ChatGPT relies on an LLM, or “large” model of these sets.
answers: grep [or global regular expression print or global slash regular expression search slash and print]
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Computer Science> ~23206~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: This concept, together with anicca or impermanence, and anattā or the “non-self,” are considered the three marks of existence. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this Sanskrit term, whose association with age, disease, and death was first witnessed by a man during his “Four Sights.” The root of this concept derives from taṇhā.
Dukkha is the first of these four Buddhist tenets taught during the Deer Park Sermon. The last of these tenets is the Eightfold Path.

In Hindu thought, release of dukkha allows one to achieve this emancipation from samsara often equated with the Buddhist concept of nirvana. In Jainism, souls classified as abhavya cannot achieve this status.
bonuses.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, RMP - Buddhism> ~23189~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: Mark Elvin’s environmental history of China is titled for the “retreat” of these creatures due to habitat destruction. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these creatures, which once formed an honor guard at the Míng court. 37 of these animals were led across the Alps by Hannibal.
Elephants have been used for centuries to gather teak, a type of this resource, from Burma. The country of Brazil is named for a type of this resource also used to make dyes.
The elephants gathering teak in Burma were commanded by riders known by this Hindi-derived term. These people often used a hook called an ankusha to goad their elephants.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22870~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: The method of lines imposes this property on all but one dimension. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property of the mesh in the finite element method that enables the approximate solving of differential equations. This property names the finest topology on a space, in which every set is open.

This Runge–Kutta method is the simplest way to numerically solve ODEs. This method, which is named for its inventor, uniformly discretizes time by iteratively adding the derivative value times the step size.
The prototypical Runge–Kutta method calculates the derivative at this many points. A Riemann sum adds areas of polygons with this many sides.
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Math> ~23140~ <Editor: David Bass
